title: Running GeneWalk
text: vignette first show Gene Walk behaves synthetic data, assumptions baked move onto using real data. want understand method detail, please check Ietswaart et al.. Let’s start synthetic data understand works… synthetic GeneWalk network designed testing benchmarking, signal genes forming coherent, degree-matched graph neighbourhoods noise genes spanning multiple ontology subtrees random. signal (“anchor”) genes clear signal. Noise genes also still due nature synthetic data; however, lesser extent. data contains everything need initialise new GeneWalk: full_data term ontology, gene gene edges gene terms, mimicking relevant inputs. genes pathways testing later. gene identifiers including run. case, set “signal” genes serve positive control “noise genes” randomly distributed. term/pathway identifiers. Let’s initialise class. function generates node2vec embedding based network. avoid instability issues due Hogwild!-type SGD used, limit threads 1L via params_genewalk(). want fast testing (parameter optimisation), can increase . Initially, generate n_graph initial representations. authors original work default 3L . need generate background distribution testing purposes. generate three random permuted networks paper. used statistical testing. now need compare similarity Cosine similarities gene embeddings pathway embeddings check often larger ones background embedding, giving us p-values. Now can extract statistics: different metrics data Let’s explore signal synthetic data bit… observing … ?  can appreciate, Cosine similarities genes pathways signal data set much higher compared FALSE ones, bimodal distribution noise genes. just accident get connected dense communities signal genes, large number just noise. Let’s look p-values  patterns Cosine similarities reproduced . can appreciate 50% signal genes significantly higher cosine similarity embedding space connected pathway. random genes, ’s ~20%. now let’s move real data. Let’s explore real data now. package provides builder factory generate objects. Within package, DuckDB contains Network resources STRING network extracted OpenTargets. SIGNOR network extracted OpenTargets. Reactome gene gene network extracted OpenTargets. Intact network extracted OpenTargets. Pathway Commons interactions, see Rodchenkov, et al.. combined network sources , based approach Barrio-Hernandez, et al.. Pathway terms Gene Ontology data extracted OBO files OBO foundry OpenTargets. Reactome pathway ontology gene pathway associations OpenTargets. Let’s use Gene Ontology combined network example. first time, database downloaded cache. wish reset DB re-download (example new release), can use reload_db(). idea factory easily iterate various bags genes interest. Now let’s use factory look specifically MYC target genes (provided package extracted Hallmarks MYC V1 gene set, see Liberzon et al.) generate GeneWalkNetwork . GeneWalk optimally work, need quite edges based interaction networks. helper get information underlying node degree: can appreciate quite interactions genes also decent number connections PPPI network. can proceed . observe low number interaction connections, likely, gene set small (noisy) approach work well (rather expected lack signal). can now use steps . Generate first three iterations real embedding based different random seeds (wish go fast add bit randomness, set num_workers ≥ 1 leverage HogWild!-style SGD word2vec implementation.). Let’s compare embeddings generate NULLs  can appreciate clearly genes higher similarities connected GO terms compared three NULLs. expected, genes highly studied connected. simple way visualise initial results use plot_results() function. tell connectivity genes within bag genes (degree + 1 x-axis), number gene <> pathway connections significant specific gene number gene <> pathway connections. options plot individual genes significantly associated terms (shown). much significant ? just pathway enrichment? Well . GeneWalk tests pre-existing edges gene pathway, given context pathway ontology interactions genes. gene prioritisation/contextualisation tool classical pathway enrichment. Nonetheless, let’s check happens noisy data… Let’s run fast many threads possible rest Let’s plot results  want use provided data … ? case, can use simple wrapper class help . Let’s show case terms internally stored Reactome data. want now get full graph dt including everything verification: want subset bag genes interest, can run following: data can easily supplied now: , can run whole approach custom network.

title: Node2vec
text: genewalkR provides quite synthetic graph data sets testing exploration purposes, namely: Barbell graph: graph two distinct clusters Cavemen graph: graph distinct communities low probability connection . Stochastic blocks: densely connected graph communities; however, cross-edges compared previous graphs. Let’s load barbell graph. Let’s transform igraph first just look data like  can appreciate nice barbell graph two distinct groups. Now let’s run node2vec data. node2vec implementation based node2vec-rs, Rust-based implementation node2vec. default setting, use HIGHLY optimised version runs CPU SIMD-acceleration tolerated race condition (undefined behaviour low level terms) makes fast. issue underlying embeddings deterministic; however, structure underlying graph identified. really, really, really need deterministic results , set n_workers = 1L. want details node2vec actually works, please, check original paper Grover Leskovec. Let’s project data onto two dimensions via PCA visualise results  can appreciate, node2vec embeddings nicely identify two groups underlying graph. Let’s look graphs well known structures Visualisation graph structure igraph first:  Let’s check node2vec graph  graph, less defined communities edges across communities.  Let’s check node2vec graph  conclusion, node2vec generates embedding underlying network structure can use visualise data additional analysis (supervised tasks like package statistical testing gene <> pathway associations bag genes). Pending needs, can go high available workers make fast, really, really, really need similar embeddings every single time, can also choose disable parallelism training.
code: library(genewalkR) library(data.table) library(magrittr) library(ggplot2) # this creates a random data set with 20 nodes per barbell cluster barbell_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "barbell",   n_nodes_per_cluster = 20L ) g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(d = barbell_data$edges, directed = FALSE)  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec barbell_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = barbell_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # the parameters are controlled via a supplied parameter list, see code here str(params_node2vec()) #> List of 10 #>  $ p             : num 1 #>  $ q             : num 1 #>  $ walks_per_node: int 40 #>  $ walk_length   : int 40 #>  $ num_workers   : int 2 #>  $ batch_size    : int 256 #>  $ n_epochs      : int 20 #>  $ n_negatives   : int 5 #>  $ window_size   : int 2 #>  $ lr            : num 0.01  # this list can be supplied and tells node2vec how to run # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(barbell_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., barbell_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster)) # generate the cavemen caveman_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "cavemen", n_clusters = 5L, p_between = 0.5 )  g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(d = caveman_data$edges, directed = FALSE)  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec cavemen_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = caveman_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(cavemen_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., caveman_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster)) # generate the stochastic block graph stochastic_block_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "stochastic_block", n_clusters = 3L, p_between = 0.05 )  g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(   d = stochastic_block_data$edges,    directed = FALSE )  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec stochastic_blocks_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = stochastic_block_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(stochastic_blocks_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., stochastic_block_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster))

text: graph_dt data.table graph information. Needs columns "", "" "type"; type must include "hierarchy" pathways, "interaction" interactions "part_of" gene/pathway interactions, optionally weight. gene_to_pathway_dt data.table gene pathway information. Needs "" (gene) "" (pathway). gene_ids String. "bag genes" testing. pathway_ids String. pathways represented network.

title: GeneWalk — GeneWalk
text: Returns initialised GeneWalk initialised object subsequent analysis.

text: graph_dt data.table contains initial graph. gene_to_pathway_dt data.table contains gene pathway connections. gene_ids genes represented gene walk list. pathway_ids pathways represented gene walk network. embds initial embedding matrices generated node2vec top graph. Depends n_graph parameter choose. permuted_embd list containing cosine distances permuted graphs.. stats data.table containing information statistical testing across permutations. params list used parameters stored.

what: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: Calculates statistical significance gene-pathway associations using GeneWalk algorithm. gene-pathway pair, function computes p-values FDR corrections (globally across pairs per-gene) across multiple network permutations. final output includes mean values 95% confidence intervals statistics. function processes permutations Rust optimal performance, calculating cosine similarities gene pathway embeddings, determining p-values based null distributions randomised networks, applying Benjamini-Hochberg FDR corrections.

title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: object GeneWalk object containing actual permuted embeddings. See GeneWalk(). .verbose Logical. TRUE, prints progress messages calculation. Default TRUE.

title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: input object added stats property containing data.table following columns gene-pathway pair: gene - Gene identifier pathway - Pathway identifier avg_pval - Mean p-value across permutations pval_ci_lower, pval_ci_upper - 95% CI p-values avg_global_fdr - Mean global FDR across permutations global_fdr_ci_lower,global_fdr_ci_upper - 95% CI global FDR avg_gene_fdr - Mean gene-wise FDR across permutations gene_fdr_ci_lower,gene_fdr_ci_upper - 95% CI gene-wise FDR

title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: Ietswaart, et al., Genome Biol, 2021

title: Generate the initial graph embedding — generate_initial_emb
text: object GeneWalk class, please see GeneWalk(). embd_dim Integer. Size embedding dimensions create. Defaults 8L line authors recommendations. n_graph Integer. many initial graphs create. Defaults 3L. genewalk_params Named list. Contains node2vec parameters. list following elements: p - Numeric. Return parameter biased random walks. Defaults 1.0. q - Numeric. -parameter biased random walks. Defaults 1.0.. walks_per_node - Integer. Number random walks per node. Defaults  100L. walk_length - Integer. Length random walk. Defaults 10L. num_workers - Number worker threads use SGD updates. determism, defaults 1L. batch_size - Integer. Batch size training. Defaults 256L. n_epochs - Integer. Number training epochs. Defaults 15L. n_negatives - Integer. Number negative samples. Defaults 5L. window_size - Integer.  Context window size. Defaults 2L. lr - Numeric. Learning rate. Defaults 1e-2. directed Boolean. Indicates directed undirected network. Defaults FALSE. seed Integer. Seed reproducibility. .verbose Boolean. Controls verbosity function

Controls verbosity function

title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: Generates synthetic network mimics real GeneWalk input data testing benchmarking. network consists three components: hierarchical ontology (tree structure lateral edges), gene--ontology annotations, protein-protein interactions (PPI). Signal genes annotated exclusively within single ontology subtree form PPI edges among , creating coherent graph neighbourhoods. Noise genes receive number annotations forced span multiple subtrees, PPI edges random across noise group. groups degree-matched significance driven annotation coherence rather connectivity alone.

title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: data_params Named list. Return params_genewalk_data(). seed Integer. Random seed. Defaults 42L.

title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: list following items: full_data data.table columns containing edges (ontology hierarchy, gene--pathway, PPI). gene_to_pathways data.table columns (gene) (pathway) gene--ontology annotation edges . gene_ids Character vector gene identifiers (signal noise). pathway_ids Character vector ontology term identifiers.
